ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Staff notation, key signature, time signature, triplets, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Integrating listening components to supplement theory was very helpful. Having even more of the listening components would have been helpful in learning to identify key signature.
It could be improved by being more introductory because I found it hard as someone with no music theory experience.
I think the class does a good job trying to train the ears of students, and make them both better versed in musical theory as well as better listeners.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I recommend the course to any student who comes from little or no background in music theory.
Yes, but only if you are passionate about music theory and learning notation.
Yes, I think the class is a good introductory level class in music theory. I also feel that it trains your ears well to make the theory you learn more applicable to everyday music listening.
